loans.use: Increasing of the variety of vegetables

loans.name: Kaniz M. Rafiq Group

texts.en:
Kaniz is 53 years old, married, and has five children. She lives with her family in Riwind, Pakistan. Her husband, M. R., has operated his own flour selling business for the past ten years. Two of Kaniz’s children work in a factory, while the younger sons are currently attending school. Kaniz believes in the value of hard work, and allows her to face each coming day. Kaniz knits and creates clothing to sell in the local market, and uses the income earned to pay the school fees. She has successfully completed three previous loans, and is now applying for another loan to sell more flour.

Kaniz is the group leader for women in the town. Hanfian baji and Sugran baji are both requesting a loan to purchase warm clothes to resell. Zubaida baji wishes to purchase cooking oil to use and vend as well.

This is a group loan. The funds will be evenly distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members will mutually cover each other’s loans- if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. They thank you advance for your generosity!

loans.use: To buy flour to sell

loans.name: Zareena Amanat Ali Group

texts.en:
My name is Zareena and I’m 55 years old married lady. I have resided in a city named Riwind, Pakistan for the past 25 years. I wasn’t priviledged enough to attend school when I was younger due to my parents little financial resources. I am married to a man whose name is A. A.. He runs a grocery shop in the community. He has a good number of customers. I am a mother of three kids: two sons and one daughter. My elder son works as a delivery man and delivers different items (construction supplies and fruits & vegetables) on his cart from one place to another. The middle child works in a factory. My daughter is 18 years old and stays at home and does household work. This work is very profitable. I save my income and a committee plans to marry off my daughter when I collect the whole amount. I have successfully repaid my first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy groceries for my husband’s grocery shop.
 
I’m a group leader of many local women. Kosar baji and Allah rakhi baji and Parveen baji each want a loan to buy buffalos for their milk selling businesses. Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Hanifan Abdul Majeed Group

texts.en:
Hanifan baji is a 40 year old married woman and a citizen of Riwind, Pakistan for the past 20 years. Her husband's name is A. M. and he works in a factory. Hanifan baji is the mother of five kids: four sons and one daughter. Her elder son is a rickshaw driver and he drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). The next eldest works in a factory. The others go to school located near their house. Hanfian baji successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She is applying again for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her son so that he will be able to run his own business and not have to pay rent as he currently does.  

She is a group leader of women of her town. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Safar

texts.ru: Шоев Сафар житель города Нурек. Возраст 38 лет, женат и имеет четверых детей. Имеет столовую . РАботает уже около пяти лет. Для того, чтобы улучшить качество обслуживантя и качество предлагаемых блюд, он планирует закупить новый инвентарь. Для этого он решил получить кредит и купить новую посуду. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Safar S. lives in Nurek. He is 38 years old and is married with four children. For the past five years he has been working in a canteen. In order to improve the quality of services and food, Safar would like to purchase new inventory. He is applying for a loan that would allow him to buy new dishware. Safar would pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Oksana Buranbaeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase inventory

loans.name: Razia M. Yousaf Group

texts.en:
Razia Baji has been a citizen of Riwind, Pakistan for the past 50 years. Her husband, M. Y., is a professional mason. Razia Baji is the mother of three kids: two daughters and one son. Her daughters work in a clothes knitting business. Razia Baji helps her daughters with knitting clothes. In addition, she goes to the market to sell them to earning additional money. Razia's son runs a grocery shop in the community. Razia Baji successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her son’s grocery shop. 

She is the leader of a group of women in her community. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy utensils to sell. Kaniz baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo to help her milk selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. If one member of the group does not repay their loan, then other members are responsible to help that member repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica P. is forty years old. She is married and the mother of two; currently, both her children have completed senior high school. She lives with her husband and the children in two-room apartment in Wasa Simpa in the western region of Ghana.

Monica has been selling coconut oil for nine years now. Coconut oil is produced from coconut fruits; she produces it and supplies it to food vendors to prepare their meals and she even treks to the villages to purchase the finished goods elsewhere when demand becomes very high.

Monica wants to use the loan to buy more bags of coconuts and an electric milling machine to increase her efficiency so as to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and raise more income to help her husband provide food for her family and finance her children's education. Monica belongs to a village bank called ‘Joy’. She hopes to receive GHS 600 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more bags of coconuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Khursheed Arif Ali Group

texts.en:
Khursheed baji is a 40-year-old married lady and a citizen of a city called Riwind, Pakistan for the past 40 years. Her husband's name is A. A. and he is a mason. Khurhseed baji has one son who works in a factory on monthly wage.

Khursheed baji belongs to a family of farmers, so she spends most of her time taking care of her buffalo. She gets up early every morning and gets milk from her and then goes to the milk shop to sell the milk. She has successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy another buffalo for her milk-selling business.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Shumaila baji wants a loan to buy wooden chairs to sell. Rifat baji wants a loan to buy bicycles for her bicycle-selling business. Hanifan baji and Sobia baji each want a loan to buy buffalos for their milk-selling businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for milk-selling business

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia A., a 28-year-old young woman is married, blessed with two children, and is a very hard-working businesswoman. Both her children are in school, and Sylvia lives with her husband in a rented house. She enjoys selling and cosmetics sales has been her major source of livelihood for the past five years. She says selling cosmetics is lucrative and her experience in the market has enabled her to gain many loyal customers.

Her shop is located at a strategic place in the market. Fortunately her shop is the first contact to enter the community market where she sells. Sylvia believes that with the loan, she would be better able to purchase more stock of cosmetics and jewelry; she needs pomade, hair cream, lipsticks etc. to increase her inventory--and income for that matter. Sylvia belongs to a village bank called ‘Joy’. She hopes to receive GHS 500 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cosmetic products

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en: Andrew has a motorcycle that he uses to convey passengers from one location to another in Asaba, Delta state, Nigeria. He is 32 years old and married with a child. He hopes for the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase another motorcycle. He says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase another motorcycle

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis E. is 26 years old. She is single and has given birth to child (a boy) who is in school. She lives with her family at Wasa Simpa in the western region of Ghana. She has been selling silver and plastic materials such as plates, buckets, bowls, cooking utensils etc. for three years now. Recently she added the sale of fruit like oranges to her product line which is frequently demanded by her clients.

For the cooking utensils, she sells them through hawking, that is, door-to-door sales. She manages to balance that with the sale of oranges. Demand for her goods is booming. She sells during the market days that fall on Wednesday in Wasa Simpa market.

She is requesting a loan to augment her working capital to buy more stock of silver and plastic materials to sell. She believes the loan will enable her to raise more income to support her family. Francis belongs to a village bank called ‘Joy’. She hopes to receive GHS 400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to send her child to school.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cooking utensils and plastics bowls and oranges

loans.name: Henrietta

texts.en:
Henrietta E. is twenty-eight years old. She is single and lives at Wasa Simpa in the western region of Ghana. She has one child whom she is taking care of in school. She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood and also sells cosmetics. Henrietta E. is very skillful and a talented hairdresser. Through the innovative touches she adds to her customers' hair, she has attracted lots of clients who come to do their hair. Henrietta has been in this business for the past five years, so she has much experience in customer care. She also has two apprentices who are learning skills for their future businesses.

Henrietta believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products such as weave-ins, pomade, shampoo, activators etc. to serve her customers. Henrietta belongs to a village bank called ‘Joy’. She hopes to receive GHS 800 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of hair products like weave-ins, pomade, shampoo, activators, etc.

loans.name: Vera

texts.en: Vera is 37 years old and married with 7 children. She lives in Asaba, Delta State, Nigeria.She has a restaurant where she sells cooked foods and drinks. She needs the loan amount of N 150,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther A. is 22 years old, married, and a mother with two children. One of her children is in school whilst the last born is breastfeeding. Esther lives with her husband at Wasa Asamang in the western region of Ghana. She dropped out of school because no one was there to support her. For that reason she decided to hook up with a man who could provide for her basic needs, and she got herself pregnant.

She has been selling cocoa drink and sachet mineral water for the past two years now. Cocoa drink is prepared with powdered cocoa; water is added to it with sugar and then it is left in a fridge for a while and it is served whilst chilled and is taken with bread. This is mostly purchased by school children because it's tasty.

Esther wants the loan to make headway so that she can buy more cocoa powder, sugar, loaves of bread and rubber bags. With the loan she believes she can produce in larger quantity. She would be grateful for your assistance. Esther belongs to a village bank called ‘God’s Time’. She hopes to receive GHS 400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: to buy more cocoa powder, sachet mineral water, etc.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 46 years old and married with 6 children. She sells provisions and foodstuffs. She is a LAPO client. She needs the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell
